citeinfo.title: Soil particle size as a function of burn severity for 2013, 2015, and 2017 in the area affected by the 2013 Black Forest Fire, Colorado USA

descript.purpose: This project investigated recovery of soil properties that influence flash flood generation in the area affected by the 2013 Black Forest Fire in Colorado, USA. Data were collected for three temporal snapshots (2013, 2105, and 2017) during a time period of four years following the wildfire to assess remaining flood hazards. Data include bulk density, loss on ignition, ground cover, soil particle size, soil-hydraulic properties, and simple infiltration modeling..

attracc.attraccr: Soil-particle size distribution was measured using dry sieving. Masses in each size fraction were measured on a digital balance. Values are summarized as percentage sand, gravel, and (silt+clay) fraction. No additional tests were conducted to assess the accuracy of values.

dataqual.logic: Data match details provided and values fall within expected ranges. Data has been checked for duplication and omission.
dataqual.complete: The dataset only represents occurrences within the area impacted by the 2013 Black Forest Fire in Colorado, USA. The datasets are complete for 2013, 2015 and 2017, with the exception that site BF2 was not sampled in 2017 because the site was compromised by soil damage from salvage logging.

procstep.procdesc:
Dry sieving techniques were used to separate soil-particle size fraction into sand, gravel, and (silt+clay) fraction based on the USDA classification.
Dry sieving methods followed Guy (1969). Cores at the sites were 6-cm long. Cores were split in 2013 according to visual estimates of distinct layering of ash and soil. In 2015 and 2017, samples were split at 0-1, 1-3, and 3-6 cm depths.
Guy HP (1969) ‘Laboratory theory and methods for sediment analysis. US Geological Survey Techniques of water-resources investigations’, Book 5, Chapter C1 (Arlington, VA)

overview.eaover: Soil-particle size distribution was measured using dry sieving. Masses in each size fraction were measured on a digital balance. Values are summarized as percentage sand, gravel, organic particles >250 micrometers, and (silt+clay) fraction. Data for soil sampling from 2013, 2015, and 2017 in the area impacted by the 2013 Black Forest Fire in Colorado. Note that site BF2 was not sampled in 2017 because the site was compromised by soil damage from salvage logging.
